review.title: Socially-Informed Timeline Generation for Complex Events
review.abstract: Existing timeline generation systems for complex events consider only information from traditional media, ignoring the rich social context provided by user-generated content that reveals representative public interests or insightful opinions. We instead aim to generate socially-informed timelines that contain both news article summaries and selected user comments. We present an optimization framework designed to balance topical cohesion between the article and comment summaries along with their informativeness and coverage of the event. Automatic evaluations on real-world datasets that cover four complex events show that our system produces more informative timelines than state-of-the-art systems. In human evaluation, the associated comment summaries are furthermore rated more insightful than editor's picks and comments ranked highly by users.

sections.heading: 2 Data Collection and Preprocessing
sections.text: We searched New York Times (NYT), CNN, and BBC news articles on four trending events: missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 (MH370), political unrest in Ukraine (Ukraine), the Israel-Gaza conflict (Israel-Gaza), and NSA surveillance leaks (NSA). For each event, we select a set of keywords (usually the entity name) used to filter out irrelevant articles. We extract comments on NYT articles via the NYT Community API and comments on CNN articles about DisqusAPI. 1 NYT comment contains information about whether a comment is an editorial selection. Statistics on the four sets of data are shown in Table 1.2. We extract parsetrees, dependency trees, and correlation resolution results from articles and comments with Stanford CoreNLP (Manning et al., 2014). Sentences in articles are labeled with timestamps using Time Chand Manning (2012).

sections.heading: 3 Joint Learning for Importance Scoring
sections.text: First, we present a common learning method based on graphics to learn two functions simultaneously - SENTENCE marking and COMMENT marking - which presupposes the importance of including an individual article or user comment in the time span. - Each article contains a series of sentences in which the individual articles and their comments are limited to parameter questions. - There is a set of comments based on a series of articles. - Each article contains a set of sentences relating to a series of sentences. - There is a set of comments based on a set of comments. - There is a set of comments referring to a set of comments.

sections.heading: 4 Timeline Generation
sections.text: Formally, our system takes for each day a set of sentences Vs and a set of comments Vc as input to be summarized, and the (automatically generated) timeline T (represented as threads) for the days preceding the current day. It then identifies a subset S'Vs as an article summary and a subset C'Vc as a comment summary by maximizing the following function: Z (S, C; T) = Squal (S; T) + Cqual (C) + δX (S, C) (6), with Squal (S; T) measuring the quality of article summary S in the context of the historical timeline represented as event threads T; Cqual (C) calculates the quality of the comment summary C; and X (S, C) estimates the connectivity between S and C. We solve this maximization problem using an alternating optimization algorithm that emerges from section 4.4.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental Results
sections.text: 5.1 Evaluation of SENTENCE and COMMENT Importance ScorersWe test importance scorers (Section 3) on single document sentence ranking and comment ranking.For both tasks, we compare with two previous systems on joint ranking and summarization of news articles and tweets. Yang et al. (2011) employ supervised learning based on factor charts to model the content similarity between the two data types. We use the same characteristics for this model. Gao et al. (2012) summarize by including the supplementary information between articles and tweets estimated by an unattended topic model.3 We also consider two state-of-the-art rankers: RankBoost (Freund et al., 2003) and LambdaMART (Burges, 2010). Finally, we use a position baseline that evaluates sentences based on their position in the article, and an assessment baseline that evaluates comments based on positive user ratings.

sections.heading: 5.2 Leveraging User Comments
sections.text: In this section, we test whether our system can use comments to generate better article-based summaries for event timelines. We collect gold standard timelines for each of the four events from the corresponding Wikipedia page (s), NYT topic page (s), or BBC news page (s). We look at two existing timeline generation systems that use news articles only, and a timeline generated from individual article human abstracts: (1) CHIEU AND LEE (2004) select sentences with high3We thank Zi Yang and Peng Li for providing the code. 4We experiment with all articles for sentence ranking, andNYT comments (with editor selection) for comment ranking. 5Similar results are obtained with average mutual ranking. "Interestiness" and "Burstiness" using a probability ratio test to compare word distributions of sentences with articles in adjacent days. (2) YAN ET AL (2011 Summary Evolution) designs a system based on selective summary evolution.

sections.heading: 5.3 Evaluating Socially-Informed Timelines
sections.text: We evaluate the full article + comment-based timelines on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Turks are presented with a timeline consisting of five consecutive article summaries and four variations of the accompanying comment summary: RANDOMly selected comments, USER'S-PICKS (rated according to positive user ratings), randomly selected EDITOR'S-PICKS and timelines created by the THREAD + OPTWordVec version of our SYSTEM. We also add a loud comment summary (i.e. irrelevant to the question) to avoid spam. We display two comments per day for each system. 6Turks are asked to classify the comment summary variations by informativeness and insightfulness. For informativeness, we ask Turks to judge only by knowledge displayed in the timeline, and each comment summary is based on how much relevant information they learn from it.

sections.heading: 5.4 Human Evaluation of Event Threading
sections.text: Here we assess the usefulness of event themes for high-level information access policies: Can event themes allow users to easily locate and absorb information if they have a particular interest in it? We randomly assigned a 10-day time frame for each set of data from the data generated by the THREAD + OPTWordVecvariation of our system. We designed a question for each timeline. Example questions are: "describe the activities in the search for missing flight MH370" and "describe the attitude and actions of the Russian government in eastern Ukraine." We assigned 10 students who speak English. Each student first read a question and the corresponding time frame for 5 minutes. The timeline was then removed and the student wrote an answer to the question. We asked each student to answer the question for each of four timelines (one for each event dataset). Two timelines are displayed with threads, and two without threads.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Existing work focuses on learning users "interests from comments and integrates the information learned into a news article summary system (Hu et al., 2008). Zhao et al. (2013) instead estimate word distributions from tweets and distort a page rank algorithm to restart sentences with a similar probability of distribution. Zhao et al. (2013) instead analyzed the generation of tweet + article summaries recently in Yang etal. (2011), proposing a factor graph that allows sentences and tweets to mutually reinforce each other. Gao et al. (2012) use a co-ranking model to identify sentence-tweet pairs with supplementary information estimated from a theme model. These efforts cover a small number of documents and tweets as we target a larger scale of data. In terms of time summaries, the Chieu and Lee (2004) system seek sentences by" dullness "and" interest "that are" calculated based on a probability rate.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We introduced a socially informed timeline generation system that constructs timelines from article summaries and comment summaries. An alternating optimization algorithm is designed to maximize connectivity between the two summaries, as well as their importance and coverage of information. Automatic and human evaluations showed that our system produced more informative timelines than modern systems. Our comment summaries were also rated highly informative.
